I would recommend to take advantage of office hours and review sessions but also to read the textbook as it is written very well.

It's Math 51. Not much left to add to what's already been said. Although it's an unpopular ranking, I would rank the lecturers in the following order: Mark>Jinyoung>Gene. Mark explains the concepts and intuition behind what we're learning a lot better than the other two lecturers. Jinyoung goes through examples in the clearest way and she is great at answering questions and overall being really supportive. Gene goes through a ton of examples in lecture and he wrote the exams in my quarter so he would give some insights that the other profs wouldn't. He was also the only lecturer that would post their annotated notes; he's a legend for that. Overall the course covers so much content and I struggled finding motivation to finish all the psets but the linear algebra is interesting and satisfying when you understand it. It's part of the stanford experience, don't hesitate to take it. Just get it over with.

Lucianovic is a really nice guy, but it's not rare that he doesn't make it all the way through the lecture notes. You'll have to teach yourself a lot of the material, but the psets are honestly really helpful and the textbook is probably the best math textbook I've ever had -- conveys the important material well, lowkey funny at times, has great resources for studying. I didn't have any multivar or linear algebra experience coming into this class and it honestly wasn't too bad, although the final did kick my butt.
Goodluck

I think we spent too much time on the basics, but then again people are coming from different backgrounds. Did not like the homework because it was very computation heavy, and there'd be several problems of the exact same type given to us. Overall a good and manageable course as advertised, learnt very helpful linear algebra. Read section worksheet solutions; those are most helpful when it comes to reviewnig for exams.

Math 51 is a great class. If you stay on top of the reading and engage with lecture it feels fairly doable. The textbook is incredibly well written and thorough and really complements the examples given in lecture (take with Gene Kim if you want very example heavy lectures).
I really did like the way the book was written and the way Gene Kim (my professor) interacted with students and made topics accessible to us.
The content in this class is extremely useful. However, it is quite challenging and you may find yourself spending hours a week studying only to scrape by on each exam.

This course is extremely fast paced. We covered about a chapter a lecture and sometimes 2 chapters. The tests are very challenging and even if you feel like you understand the concepts that doesn't mean you'll be able to answer the questions.
Don't take it unless you have to. Interesting stuff, but too much content in too little time.
Difficult class but had to do it for a major requirement

MATH 51 is MATH 51 -- the beginning of the course was very confusing, the second part was understandable, and the end expanded greatly on previous knowledge. The teaching quality is okay, but zero accommodations were made for me when I tested positive for COVID. The lectures aren't recorded, but the annotated notes usually suffice. However, be aware that many of the annotated notes have typos and wrong math in them.
Gene Kim was a good lecturer. Interesting class with wide-applications.

If you want to obtain a good grade in Math 51 is definitely a strong 5 units. The instruction is fine, but you will have to do a lot of the learning yourself outside of class. Homework is application of theory learned in class to problems rather than just learning how to work through problems. Section is not mandatory, but can be helpful some weeks.

Learn to use outside resources, kahn academy, etc. The teachers are pretty good but the class moves so fast that if you are not solid on one topic while its being taught in class/ going over it in discussion, the class will move on anyways and not mention the topic again. It will only come up later on a midterm/final.
Challenging but very rewarding class! Will learn alot! Go to Jinyoung's lecture!!!!
As someone not confident in math, this class felt like 8 units. Also donEt get behind. Ever.

I learned a ton about linear algebra, multivariable calculus, and general math skills form this course. While it is a lot of work, the course is very useful for everything that uses some of linear algebra.
Keep up with the pace of this class and you will be fine! Hard work but definitely doable.
Its hard but its fair for the most part. The exams are a bit tricky.
Very difficult class. Be ready for the challenge
its hard but rewarding

This class is HARD. The midterms are not like the homework, class problems, or practice midterms. This class prides itself off pitting students against each other and encouraging them to fail. This class severely harmed my mental health. The worst part is that this class is a pre-req or requirement for like every single major, you would think they would be super accommodating and helpful, however they are not. None of my accommodations were met, and this class just does not care about the students in it. There are literally students that fail midterms but understand the material. This class does not accurately determine a student's knowledge. If by some miracle you do not have to take this class, then don't. If you are considering CME 100 or Math 51 take CME 100.
